Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell has taken of late to praising legendary Chairman Paul Volcker, as a signal of his new inflation-fighting determination.
Mr. Powell further contributed to the good cheer by saying the economy remains strong, blowing past the first quarter decline in gross domestic product.
Paul Volcker was a subtle central banker, but one lesson from his career is that when the Fed decides to break inflation, better to go ahead and do it.
But Mr. Powell put Tall Paul on hold on Wednesday as he walked back some of the hawkishness that he and his colleagues have exhibited in recent weeks.
Yet Democratic candidate Rep. Tim Ryan, in contrast to others in his party, doesn't seem to think that running against Trumpism is a winning strategy.

The history of rapid inflation is that it takes a fed funds rate that is higher than the pace of price increases to break inflation.
If Mr. Powell is right that inflation is about to head downward, and perhaps rapidly, then his slow pace of tightening may pay off.
Even if the Fed follows with a pair of 50 basis point increases at its next two meetings, real interest rates will remain negative.

But the news is that Mr. Powell signaled the Fed may not need to be as aggressive to counter inflation as markets had thought.
And he signaled a slower pace of decline in the Feds bond portfolioaka, quantitative tighteningcompared to previous hints.

The one thing he and the Fed dont want to concede is that the central bank is largely to blame.
